metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: JavaScript Objects
Real Life Objects
In real life, objects are things like: houses, cars, people, animals, or any other subjects.
content.html: In real life, objects are things like: houses, cars, people, animals, or any other subjects.

content.text: Here is a car object example:
content.html: Here is a car object example:

content.text: Object Properties
A real life car has properties like weight and color:
content.html: A real life car has properties like weight and color:

content.text: car.name = Fiat, car.model = 500, car.weight = 850kg, car.color = white.
content.html: car.name = Fiat, car.model = 500, car.weight = 850kg, car.color = white.

content.text: Car objects have the same properties , but the values differ from car to car.
content.html: Car objects have the same properties, but the values differ from car to car.

content.text: Object Methods
A real life car has methods like start and stop:
content.html: A real life car has methods like start and stop:

content.text: car.start(), car.drive(), car.brake(), car.stop().
content.html: car.start(), car.drive(), car.brake(), car.stop().

content.text: Car objects have the same methods , but the methods are performed at different times .
content.html: Car objects have the same methods, but the methods are performed at different times.

content.text: JavaScript Variables
JavaScript variables are containers for data values.
content.html: JavaScript variables are containers for data values.

content.text: This code assigns a simple value (Fiat) to a variable named car:
content.html: This code assigns a simple value (Fiat) to a variable named car:

content.code_html: let car = "Fiat";

content.text: JavaScript Objects
Objects are variables too. But objects can contain many values.
content.html: Objects are variables too. But objects can contain many values.

content.text: This code assigns many values (Fiat, 500, white) to an object named car:
content.html: This code assigns many values (Fiat, 500, white) to an object named car:

content.code_html: const car = {type:"Fiat", model:"500", color:"white"};

content.text: Note:
It is a common practice to declare objects with the const keyword.
content.html: It is a common practice to declare objects with the const keyword.

content.text: Learn more about using const with objects in the chapter: JS Const .
content.html: Learn more about using const with objects in the chapter: JS Const.

content.text: JavaScript Object Definition
How to Define a JavaScript Object
JavaScript Object Literal
An object literal is a list of name:value pairs inside curly braces {} .
content.html: An object literal is a list of name:value pairs inside curly braces {}.

content.code_html: {firstName:"John", lastName:"Doe", age:50, eyeColor:"blue"}

content.text: Note:
name:value pairs are also called key:value pairs .
content.html: name:value pairs are also called key:value pairs.

content.text: object literals are also called object initializers .
content.html: object literals are also called object initializers.

content.text: Creating a JavaScript Object
These examples create a JavaScript object with 4 properties:
content.html: These examples create a JavaScript object with 4 properties:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
// Create an Object
const person = {firstName:"John", lastName:"Doe", age:50, eyeColor:"blue"};

content.code:
// Create an Object
const person = {firstName:"John", lastName:"Doe", age:50, eyeColor:"blue"};

syntax_highlighting.text:
// Create an Object
const person = {firstName:"John", lastName:"Doe", age:50, eyeColor:"blue"};

content.code_html:
// Create an Object
 const person = {firstName:"John", lastName:"Doe", age:50, eyeColor:"blue"};

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
// Create an Object
const person = {firstName:"John", lastName:"Doe", age:50, eyeColor:"blue"};

content.text: Using the new Keyword
This example create a new JavaScript object using new Object() , and then adds 4 properties:
content.html: This example create a new JavaScript object using new Object(), and then adds 4 properties:

content.code_html:
// Create an Object
 const person = new Object();

// Add Properties
 person.firstName = "John";
person.lastName = "Doe";
person.age = 50;
person.eyeColor = "blue";

content.text: Note:
The examples above do exactly the same.
content.html: The examples above do exactly the same.

content.text: But, there is no need to use new Object() .
content.html: But, there is no need to use new Object().

content.text: For readability, simplicity and execution speed, use the object literal method.
content.html: For readability, simplicity and execution speed, use the object literal method.

content.text: Object Properties
The named values , in JavaScript objects, are called properties .
content.html: The named values, in JavaScript objects, are called properties.

content.text: Objects written as name value pairs are similar to:
content.html: Objects written as name value pairs are similar to:

content.text: Accessing Object Properties
You can access object properties in two ways:
content.html: You can access object properties in two ways:

content.code_html: objectName.propertyName
person.lastName;

content.text: JavaScript Object Methods
Methods are actions that can be performed on objects.
content.html: Methods are actions that can be performed on objects.

content.text: Methods are function definitions stored as property values .
content.html: Methods are function definitions stored as property values.

content.code_html:
const person = {
  firstName: "John",
  lastName : "Doe",
  id       : 5566,
  fullName : function() {
    return this.firstName + " " + this.lastName;
  }
};

content.text: In the example above, this refers to the person object :
content.html: In the example above, this refers to the person object:

content.text: this.firstName means the firstName property of person .
content.html: this.firstName means the firstName property of person.

content.text: this.lastName means the lastName property of person .
content.html: this.lastName means the lastName property of person.

content.text: In JavaScript, Objects are King.
If you Understand Objects, you Understand JavaScript.
Objects are containers for Properties and Methods .
content.html: Objects are containers for Properties and Methods.

content.text: Properties are named Values .
content.html: Properties are named Values.

content.text: Methods are Functions stored as Properties .
content.html: Methods are Functions stored as Properties.

content.text: Properties can be primitive values, functions, or even other objects.
content.html: Properties can be primitive values, functions, or even other objects.

content.text: In JavaScript, almost "everything" is an object.
content.html: In JavaScript, almost "everything" is an object.

content.text: All JavaScript values, except primitives, are objects.
content.html: All JavaScript values, except primitives, are objects.

content.text: JavaScript Primitives
A primitive value is a value that has no properties or methods.
content.html: A primitive value is a value that has no properties or methods.

content.text: 3.14 is a primitive value
content.html: 3.14 is a primitive value

content.text: A primitive data type is data that has a primitive value.
content.html: A primitive data type is data that has a primitive value.

content.text: JavaScript defines 7 types of primitive data types:
content.html: JavaScript defines 7 types of primitive data types:

content.text: Immutable
Primitive values are immutable (they are hardcoded and cannot be changed).
content.html: Primitive values are immutable (they are hardcoded and cannot be changed).

content.text: if x = 3.14, you can change the value of x, but you cannot change the value of 3.14.
content.html: if x = 3.14, you can change the value of x, but you cannot change the value of 3.14.

content.text: JavaScript Objects are Mutable
Objects are mutable: They are addressed by reference, not by value.
content.html: Objects are mutable: They are addressed by reference, not by value.

content.text: If person is an object, the following statement will not create a copy of person:
content.html: If person is an object, the following statement will not create a copy of person:

content.code_html: const x = person;

content.text: The object x is not a copy of person. The object x is person.
content.html: The object x is not a copy of person. The object x is person.

content.text: The object x and the object person share the same memory address.
content.html: The object x and the object person share the same memory address.

content.text: Any changes to x will also change person:
content.html: Any changes to x will also change person:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // This will change age in person:

syntax_highlighting.text: // This will change age in person:

content.code_html:
//Create an Object
 const person = {
  firstName:"John",
  lastName:"Doe",
  age:50, eyeColor:"blue"
}

// Try to create a copy
 const x = person;

// This will change age in person:
 x.age = 10;

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // This will change age in person:

content.text: Note:
You will learn a lot more about objects in the following chapters.
content.html: You will learn a lot more about objects in the following chapters.

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
Consider the following object: const car = { brand: 'Volvo', model: 'EX90' }; How many properties do the object have?
content.html:
Consider the following object:
const car = {
  brand: 'Volvo',
  model: 'EX90'
};
How many properties do the object have?

metadata.question: Consider the following object:const car = {  brand: 'Volvo',  model: 'EX90'};How many properties do the object have?
